Thanks Tim!

This causes issues if you run Swift on RHEL9/CentOS Stream 9 with FIPS enabled. In that case any tempurl fails with sth like this:

    _hashlib.UnsupportedDigestmodError: Unsupported digestmod functools.partial(<function __hash_new at 0x7f90e78f11f0>, 'sha1')

The easiest way to reproduce this is to launch a CentOS Stream 9 VM, enable FIPS ("fips-mode-setup --enable && reboot") and run the following code:

    import hashlib
    import hmac
    import functools
    
    key = "mykey".encode('utf8')
    msg = b"hello world"
    
    digestmod = functools.partial(hashlib.new, "sha1")
    print(hmac.new(key, msg, digestmod).hexdigest())

The failing non-voting FIPS job looks like a deployment issue, will look into this.

that seam very long.
i dont have the full context but we shoudl be able to deprecate this in Z an dremove in AA or AB

so Z+1 or Z+2 the new life cycle will only come into effect form AA to CC and as long as we deprecate in Z or AA we can drop it in B so why z+4 that more then double what is required.
Sorry, my math is flaky. :) But you get the point. To answer when we can drop the migration code, I should know how far neutron allows to skip releases, if at all.

upstream neutron only support n to n+1

ffu is not supported by upstream projects.

so our minium deprecation is 1 cycle then we can remove in the next.

that will change in the CC release.

AA will be our tick release and in CC we will only be able to remove things that were deprecated in zed or AA. we will no be able to remove things deprecated in BB since it was not depercated in teh previous tick

but we will be able to drop things in DD that were deprecated in BB sicne the deprecation will have been included in CC.

so if we deprecate something in zed it can be removedin AA or BB
if we deprecate in AA it can be remvoed in BB or CC
if we deprecte in BB or CC it can be removed in DD or later.
since removals under the new lifcycle policy will require deprecation in the a tick release before they can be removed.



so no we do not allow skiping releases today and never have.
in the future we will alow skipping exactly one release but the first release to supprot that will be CC which woudl allow skiping form AA to CC skiping BB.

What's the upstream neutron upgrade procedure? Whatever the number of releases allowed to skip between upgrades without running maintenance tasks, the number of releases to carry the migration code should be this number *2, no?

So if e.g. we don't allow to skip releases, users will get the maintenance task with Z and we can safely remove it for AA, 0*2 releases later. But if we e.g. allow to skip 1 release, we can remove it only in AB since we would be sure that if a user didn't receive the migration path with Z, they definitely received it with AA.

Is the upgrade between releases documented anywhere? Also, LTS releases, if any, should be considered.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
for context cold migration between differnt backend or firewall dirvers is not supprot today. it was intentionall not supported when we added support for live migration across backends.

so this is a new feature not a bug.

TL;DR we only support cross backend migration if you use multiple port bindigns and we do not support that for cold migraiton in general. supporting it for cold migration was inentionally gated on nueton requiring all backend to support multiple port bidnings. that never happened so we do not support it.


if you read the nova spec you can see that it only talks about support this for live migration

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/rocky/implemented/neutron-new-port-binding-api.html

it make some refrence to other move operation but we only implemnted multiple port biding for livemigration at the tiem and intentionally exluced cold migration.

we had planned ot port cold migration to use multile port binding whne neutron started to require all backends to supprt multipel port bindigns.

that has to this day still not happened. we planned to remove the support for move operation without multiple port bindign with two cycles.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/rocky/implemented/neutron-new-port-binding-api.html#proposed-change

form a nova perspecitve there was ans still is very little value in support multiple port bidning and therefore the ablity to cold migrate across network backend if we also have to supprot the legacy flow so that is why we have never offically supported this upstream and why we do not support id downstream.

Thanks for the review, I'll update it to treat it as a feature. However, is this documented somewhere? My understanding was that Neutron introduced the multiple port binding API to be able to have mixed environments with nodes supporting hybrid plug and nodes that do not. Was cold migration specifically excluded as a supported operation? Shall it fail then when attempting to migrate between two different plugging mechanisms or will this "feature" be enough to support such operation?

it's a one-direction, supporting both has little to no sense in the end, especially since iptables isn't "iptables", but a wrapper around "nftables" called "iptables-nft". There's still the iptables-legacy, but we don't install it anyway.

Basically, we're removing a compatibility layer.

Goal is to move jobs to nftables - so yeah, we'll consume this one as we're moving a selected amount of jobs to this engine and "sit for a while". This can also be testprojects, but I'd rather get actual jobs in order to ensure everything's working before the big jump.

I can add the |length check as well, but iirc, empty string is undefined. Since it's a temporary thing, we MAY be safe as-is.
Is move to nftables one-direction? Are we gonna need to support nftables and iptables?

Do you have a reference to these tuning parameters? The bug report that Brian links doesn't mention these, either. While tuning devstack certainly is a valid thing, I would ask why python and/or the OpenStack services don't have sensible defaults. IMO it doesn't help much if devstack tests works fine but every real world deployment will blow up later anyway.
Might want to add "Related-bug: #1908805".  This might give operators some pointers on things to look into in their infrastructure configuration.
In the last mallopt call it's not M_MMAP_THRESHOLD but M_TRIM_THRESHOLD

These tuning parameters are presented here https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Memory-Allocation-Tunables.html

Tuning these options is needed because glibc changed and it now creates 1 memory arena for each native thread instead of sharing it between them like before.

I evaluated setting these in the Python Services themselves and discarded it because it is a bit "hackish", as we can't set these env vars in Python ourselves because by the time the Python code is evaluated glibc has already been loaded and seen the environmental variable values.  The alternative is to call C code directly like this:

  # These values are defined in /usr/include/malloc.h
  M_TRIM_THRESHOLD = -1
  M_MMAP_THRESHOLD = -3
  M_ARENA_MAX = -8

  import ctypes
  libc = ctypes.CDLL('libc.so.6')
  libc.mallopt(ctypes.c_int(M_ARENA_MAX), ctypes.c_int(1))
  libc.mallopt(ctypes.c_int(M_MMAP_THRESHOLD), ctypes.c_int(131072))
  libc.mallopt(ctypes.c_int(M_MMAP_THRESHOLD), ctypes.c_int(262144))

I'm also changing these values in TripleO so that these changes are also applied in those deployments: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/845807
Does it have any performance impact? Is it save to use it for production? Thank you.
Have to check performance.json for other services

I tested it on the cinder-backup service and there doesn't seem to have a significant performance impact.

In my tests I run 2000 backups and 2000 restores with concurrency 10 both with and without the environmental variables and the results were:

- Peak memory usage dropped from 2.9GB to 1.2GB.
- Memory at rest after the whole process dropped from 2GB to 140MB.

There were additional tests, but this was the largest one, and in all of them the high water mark issue (memory at rest) was resolved.

Performance wise the full tests took 1.44% longer with the changes (from 11 hours and 3 minutes to 11 hours and 12 minutes), but these numbers could be caused by external factors such as room temperature (one was run at night while the other during the day, in summer), etc.

I would recommend you do your own independent tests before going to production with the changes, and we would love to hear your results.
thank you very much for the feedback! We indeed are testing this patch ourselves. We are happy to find the memory usage is dropping. I will report to you later if performance test result comes out.
I can't see any huge memory consumption difference for other services, so changing the patch to only modify c-vol and c-bak.  I'll do the same for the tripleo patch.

I see that non-RBD pools also get created by "add_pools" function. Do we need to set the "rbd" pool application label for them as well?

This code creates:

- glance pool (see L651)
- cinder pool (see L663)
- cinder bak pool (see L663)
- nova pool (see L668)

We set rbd for all of them because are explicitly created (and needs to be 'rbd' as we do in TripleO and ceph-ansible), and the application is not a parameter here (there's basically no need for extra logic to associate a particular application to a particular pool). 
The other pools (like cephfs_{data && metadata} are created by orchestrator, so we're good in terms of application as we don't have to set it.

Extra logic will be added in future changes only if needed, otherwise the goal can still be feature parity with the old ceph plugin.

nodepool/builder.py.message:
Also are you sure that this should be patched instead of patching https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/openstack/provider.py#L216 to require only uuid and get name by it?

At this point it feels like providers are not in sync about amount of arguments to accept. And it also feels, like accepting single argument would be more correct, but not sure.

It definetely will keep failing with TypeError at least because following methods in AWS, Azure and IBM VPC drivers accept only one parameter:

https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/azure/adapter.py#L479

https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/aws/adapter.py#L343

https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/ibmvpc/adapter.py#L523

I learned sources for a while and found an interface-class for adapters (https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/statemachine.py#L808) with same named method `deleteImage(external_id)` taking exactly one parameter.
Though provider for OpenStack (https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/openstack/provider.py#L40) doesn't inherit that class excplicitly, they both have a common methods supposed to provide the same functionality and probably might have same signatures (`deleteImage()`, `uploadImage()`). 

So i would propose getting rid from `name` parameter in the following lines:
https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/openstack/provider.py#L216
https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/statemachine.py#L667
as Dmitriy suggested above. As a quick fix. 

Further maybe there will be good to see reimplementing of base classes for all drivers to enhance uniformity of interfaces.

I agree that it would be cool to rewrite code for the openstack provider and make it using statemachine, but does this mean that purposed fix isn't an option and It should be solved by the provider refactor?

No, I was suggesting that the change as written is correct. You don't need to rewrite openstack to use statemachine in order to fix this. I was responding to the suggestion above that suggested patching a different part of the code. The providers are in sync. They all use the same interface.
does this mean that I have to refactor openstack provider to use statemachine instead of just additional argument passing?

As mentioned perviously the manager.deleteImage() call should be https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/statemachine.py#L667 which then calls the methods listed above that only accept the id parameter. What this means is that everything is currently in sync except for this driver.

We should not need to rewrite the openstack driver to use statemanager to fix this. The proposed fix should be fine. Separately rewriting the driver to use statemanager may be a good idea but I do not think it is necessary here and a significant amount of work in comparison.

Basically lets fix the bug in the most straightforward manner (which I believe this change already does), then followup with any suggested refactoring to reduce confusion.

I don't think this code was ever correct. This should call into https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/driver/statemachine.py#L667 for all of the drivers which has the same signature whether aws or openstack or azure.

As an addendum to my previous comment about switching to firewalld, I'm not the firewalld expert, but it seems like we could enable firewalld and then set up a 'devstack' zone and add an interface to it and then just accept all traffic on that particular devstack interface.

 sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --new-zone=devstack
 sudo firewall-cmd --zone=devstack --change-interface=${INTERFACE_OF_HOSTIP}
 sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --zone=devstack --set-target=ACCEPT

with a 

 sudo firewall-cmd --reload

probably thrown in there somewhere. Or just move the interface the existing 'trusted' zone.

We don't currently do anything with interface names, so maybe that'd be a pain. Could probably just add a rich rule based on "destination address=$HOST_IP" as well.

But functionally on a single nic devstack system that would be equivalent to the current patch which just disables firewalld. Which I'm not really against, it's devstack and like Daniel said ubuntu doesn't block anything by default. It would just give people the option of specifying a public/private interface with different rules, and if we ever wanted to having the zone would make it easy to add rules for individual services if we ever went crazy and did that. :p

The same approach is used by the other core plugins like VTS, Mellanox or NSX. If we fix this then we should fix all these services as well as relevant environment files. This expands scope of this change too much.

I will leave it now as a follow up and we can discuss it later.
but still i think it's better to explicit disable in resource mappings.

This resource is not assigned to any roles so this definition has no effect.

What is tricky here is that we do not use NeutronCorePluginML2Ansible directly but use that resource to override OS::TripleO::Services::NeutronCorePlugin (which I missed previously). See how the resource is enabled in the environment files.

If we disable these services by default then there is no benefit of keeping these individual plugin services(as we need to define an individual plugin service first and the override the core plugin service by the individual plugin service).

I think the better approach is to remove the all NeutronCorePlugin* services and directly override the NeutronCorePlugin service by individual resource template in environment files.

eg)
```
resource_registry:
  OS::TripleO::Services:NeutronCorePlugin: deployment/deprecated/neutron/neutron-plugin-ml2-ansible-container-puppet.yaml
```

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> As a black-box that outputs a bunch of boilerplate YAML, the golang stuff is probably something that most contributers could deal with.
> 
> As for other operators importing golang from this repo: I don't think we should support that.  Ultimately, our goal here is to provide a Zuul operator; not to provide a building block for other people to build operators on top of.  The current implementation is Python, which is an implementation detail no one should care about.  How we build the openapi schema is an even more minor implementation detail that people should care about even less.  In other words, we should feel free to change anything about those at any time with no regard to other users.  So I don't think we should do anything that leads people to believe that anything other than Kubernetes resources are an expected API for the operator.
> 

I'm not sure to understand, the go structs just define the Kubernetes resources. They can be used to create the Zuul object using a runtime client (https://pkg.go.dev/sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime/pkg/client#Object), instead of relying on the unstructured package. 

We would like to use the zuul-operator to manage the zuul service for the sf-operator, and having the go definition provides a useful API. Perhaps others might be interested in having such resources definition available.

> Given that, plus the fact that we don't expect frequent changes to the CRD, I'm not sure the additional complexity/maintenance of the build machinery for this is worth it.

If you prefer I can remove the go code, but I find it easier that way to maintain the openapi schema. Moreover we might need a few more CRDs to implement backup and restore of the zuul secrets.

I'm wondering if we should actually support etcd as a backend, or just go straight to the raft based integrated storage provided with Vault in newer versions (see [1] and [2]). This would further remove additional requirements of applications.

The move to integrated storage doesn't necessarily remove the need to support different backends in a flexible way - but may not run into some of the various tangles involved with the current interfaces without running into awkwardness in the migration paths, etc.

[1] - https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/internals/integrated-storage
[2] - https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/configuration/storage/raft

Since this is my first time working with vault and reactive charms, I flagged some things in the patch that I'm not sure about, and would appreciate some feedback/comments/thoughts if someone has time. :)  Thanks.

Billy, please see Nobuto's response here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/vault-charm/+bug/1883242/comments/8

TL;DR: it seems that supporting the raft integrated storage would be good, but would also be a large task and most likely break backwards compatibility in some way too.

It's just unfortunate that the original design with the storage relations and behaviour was somewhat shortsighted.

If we're ok with breaking backwards compatibility, or developing a 'v2' of this charm, then we can absolutely come up with a neat design.  But for now, I'm not sure how to model this less awkwardly.

src/config.yaml.message: This is modeled quite awkwardly. Typically we'd use relations to define the storage backend and have an appropriate interface, however I realize that this was scoped to database relations which further makes this awkward.

Maybe another way could be to add new relation types (storage-backend-X: interface: X and ha-storage-backend-X: interface: X).  Similar to what was proposed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-vault/+/751692

However, it's still going to be confusing, because we'll need to retain the 'db', 'shared-db', and 'etcd' relations and the previous behaviour with those.  And it will not be obviousl how they work.

An aside: what is the usual expected behaviour when two mutually exclusive relations are attached (eg. with the current case if 'db' and 'shared-db' are attached)?  Should it throw an error and stop the services?  Should it prefer one over the other?  Should it randomly flipflop between them depending on the order that the hooks are called (which from inspecting the code, will be the current behaviour as far as I can tell)?

I know, I don't like it either.  However I was assuming backwards compatibility was required, and the previous behaviour was also modeled awkwardly...

If we're ok with dropping complete backwards compatibility, we can do it quite elegantly using relations.

By the way, what does happen when it's needed to make a backwards incompatible change in a charm?  As far as I can tell, charms are treated as rolling release and could be updated at any time, which is bad news if we modify the behaviour.
I'm not sure that this would be clear to users on the difference between storage-backend and ha-storage-backend.

Probably not.  But we do need to be able to control both independently if we want to support current behaviour (which allows for mysql storage backend and etcd ha storage backend) and future desired behaviour (mysql for both, etcd for both, and potentially raft for both).

If the docs here were expanded, would that satisfy?  How technical are we assuming end users to be?

Normally I wouldn't think this would be a super important change. Even though the justification from the recently-changed PUT operation applies here, the case for doing this is much weaker for DELETE, IMHO. The 200 PUT was telling the user something untrue - that the cache operation was done, and converting to 202 was important signaling. For DELETE, 200->204 doesn't signal anything other than "I'm not returning the object to you" which is not nearly as important.

However, here are some points in favor of doing this:

- The spec says 204
- The API-REF says 204
- All the other delete operations in glance are 204
- It's admin-only so not widely-used
- It's less than a cycle old

So I'm kinda meh about it, and wish we had microversions to cleanly signal this. However, we did bump the image service version for the PUT change. Are we saying this is covered under that as well because we only need one bump per release or what?

If others are okay with this then I am too, but let's make sure.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is a patch disallowed from being sw-patch delete' while it's in Partial-Remove state?
I think that is a typo.   (delete it)  should be removed from the test description, as sw-patch will indicate that the patch is not in Available state.

It's not a typo. It was a test case that was failing previously.
sw-patch remove -> Moves patch to Partial-Remove state 
sw-patch delete -> Throws an error (as expected) but still moves the patch to Available state. So when you re-run the delete command, it allows you to delete the patch (as it is in the available state now) which is wrong.

And to answer John's question - yes, a patch is disallowed from being deleted if it is in the Partial-Remove state.

Thinking about this more, I think the current change here is really a bit roundabout, still looping through all firmware files and then trying to warn (but not block) at the end.

It seems like the real bug here is "we should never have considered the secboot file if platform==pc". If that's the case, it seems like the better algorithm here should be something like:

 firmwares = NON_SECBOOT_FIRMWARE_PATH_LIST
 if platform == 'q35':
     firmwares.append(SECBOOT_FIRMWARE_PATH)
 for firmware in firmwares:
     ...

So that we're not even iterating the list with the secboot file in it if we know it can't work on our platform.

Either way, I'm still pretty meh about applying this to such old branches at this point, but I'll defer to people with stronger opinions.

This feels like something that's maybe too invasive for something as old as Ussuri and Victoria, as it's not a regression, not security, etc. I also question whether it's generally applicable or specific to where that file will be on ubuntu. Wouldn't it make more sense to push this into the ubuntu package as an almost-feature-backport sort of thing?
some minior nits but having discussed this with you i agree that this should be done as a stable only change.

Yup, I tried to be conservative w/ the changes; happy to use another structure/take suggestions!

This is generally applicable / not specific to Ubuntu -- any distro/install with the .secboot.fd file will hit this issue.

Having this downstream in Ubuntu is indeed an option, but offering this upstream as other distros might hit this (and, honestly, to ask for review/opinions from other developers on good ways to do it) seemed a natural path forward.

[root@controller-0 sysadmin(keystone_admin)]# dpkg -s sudo-ldap
Package: sudo-ldap
Status: install ok installed
Priority: optional

Architecture: amd64
Source: sudo
Version: 1.9.5p2-3
Replaces: sudo

The virtual sudo package satisfies dependency from sudo-config etc.

openstack_auth/views.py.message: The redirect_to is supposed to be an URL in this case, the fact that Django tries to resolve a view name if it doesn't look like an URL is unintended. Maybe it would be better to just create a HttpResponseRedirect directly here, always treating redirect_to as an URL?

The way shortcuts.redirect works, you can use it to either redirect to an url, or to a view name. The error can only happen with the latter case, when the view you reference doesn't exist — if you redirect to an url, it will always work. In this particular case, Horizon only ever redirects to an URL. So if we switched from using shortcuts.redirect to creating the HttpResponseRedirect oourselves here, we could avoid the error completely, because it only happens for a case that we don't use here anyways.
Having said that, I'm perfectly fine with catching the error.

I think Randomir's suggestion is to replace the first shortcuts.redirect (at L.304)  with HttpResponseRedirect (as "redirect_to" always contains an URL in horizon and we don't need to resolve it as a view name). If so, we will get 404 instead of 500.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi Baptiste. I understand the motivation for this, however we need to consider the impact on Ironic. Currently we synchronously update the port binding, meaning that provisioning will not proceed until the network is configured. If we make binding asynchronous from network configuration we will have a race condition, where the network may not be ready when the node boots.

Years ago there was an effort to fix this in Ironic to make it asynchronous and handle the port state notifications, however it was not finished. Perhaps it would be easier now with deploy steps in Ironic, but I expect it will still be difficult. 

An alternative would be to poll the port in Ironic to wait until it becomes active.

Hi,

Just to clarify: with this initial patch, port creation/update is still synchronous. That being said, I haven't tested the impact of the patch on Ironic (we don't use Ironic), and the goal was to trigger a discussion.

You're right, our end-goal is to make port creation asynchronous to be able to apply optimizations in NGS. One of the ways I'm exploring would be to return ports with status="BUILD" while they are still being configured, and the client would then have to poll the port status or wait for a notification from Neutron.

Looking at the Ironic code, it's already doing this for smartnic ports in several places, such as:

    wait_for_port_status(client, port.id, 'ACTIVE')

https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/8aaf2e08c074e786767a24adbbe3afec5ff622c3/ironic/common/neutron.py#L352

It looks like the same could be done for baremetal ports managed by NGS, but again I'm not well versed in Ironic.

In any case, I'm happy to leave this patch on hold while we explore applicable solutions.
Thanks, LGTM - agree with Douglas' suggestion as well;

tempest/api/volume/admin/test_backends_c.message: These are defined in cinder.common.constants .  I guess we can't import them because we don't want to make cinder a dependency for tempest.  But it would be good to have a comment here saying where these are coming from in case they get out of sync at some point and someone has to track this down.  You should also point out that the canonical name for the storage protocol comes first in the list (since your code change below depends on that).

I think we want this comment to be more explicit about what's going on, because otherwise, it looks like the test is massaging the response to make the test pass, which is not something a test should do.

So maybe something along the lines of:

Cinder Bug #1966103: Some drivers were reporting different strings to represent the same storage protocol.  For backward compatibility, the scheduler can handle the variants, but to standardize this for operators (who may need to refer to the protocol in volume-type extra-specs), the get-pools response was changed by I07d74078dbb1 to only report the canonical name for a storage protocol.  Thus, the expected_list (which we got from the get-pools call) will only contain canonical names, while the observed_list (which we got from the driver capabilities call) may contain a variant.  So before comparing the lists, we need to look for known variants in the observed_list elements and replace them with their canonical values.

The broad search can also prevent from this bug happening again in case ONTAP just decides to answer even more things.
In a login scenario (which is the only thing being done with this function in the code), ONTAP used to respond only: 
"Password:"
After some ONTAP releases (and if the last login info display was enabled by the cluster admin), it started responding:
"Last login attempt <date and time> \n
Password:"
So if we make this specific searches now as it was in the past, depending on how it is modified, there might be need to modify this in the future too, in case ONTAP starts reporting even more stuff in the login.

src/reactive/vault_handlers.py.message:
My gut feeling is that you can just put `service_reload` after writing the certificate here.

Even if CA cert is updated, I don't believe the reload/restart of the service is necessary.

> Isn't the CA used in the certificate chain?

I don't believe so. The CA is written to /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/vault-ca.crt and it's to be used when Vault connects to other services, not to accept connections to Vault.
Oh ok.  Isn't the CA used in the certificate chain?  Or is the CA here unrelated to the previous cert/key?

Does service_reload return 0 even when vault is not yet started? If that's the case, I think we can put this service_reload just before `set_flag('configured')` a few lines above without any conditions.

The benefits are:
- no additional flag like vault.ssl.updated
- can reload other certificates like /var/snap/vault/common/etcd-cert.pem (for etcd) and /var/snap/vault/common/db-tls-ca.pem (for mysql)

What do you think?

> Does service_reload return 0 even when vault is not yet started?

Not sure about this.

But your comment sounds like a good idea (although I can't actually see where configure_vault is triggered apart from when mysql or psql are available in configure_vault_psql and configure_vault_mysql... but that may be a bug for another time).  How about unconditionally reloading vault in that same location?  It shouldn't have any ill effect, and doesn't change any assumptions - the code already expects to be able to restart the vault service at this point, so requesting a live reload here should be fine.

How does it look now?

templates/usr.bin.nova-compute.message:
Hi Nobuto-San,

Thanks for the detailed explanation. I had this concern mostly from looking at other entries, like `/dev/nbd* rw`. I can't tell all the possible problem ramifications related to from using `/dev/*` vs `/dev/vd*`, but the correct policy would always to concede the minimum permission possible for any kind of restrictive filter. The filter you mention (/dev/disk/**) likely did that because of the complex and unpredictable possible naming which I believe is not the case here.

But looking closely at the error log, I can see that lsscsi is explicitly trying to open read /dev/. So, it would not work using my suggestion.

We should restrict this a bit more if possible. 

```
/dev/vd* r
```
?

Also, I don't believe `/dev/vd* r` is a limited scope than `/dev/ r`. The former has a read permission to the content of the file (drive in this case), but the latter only gives a read permission to the directory because of non wildcard policy (`ls /dev/` basically).

It's worth noting that nova-compute policy has the following permission already, which is way more power to me:
  /dev/disk/** r,
  /dev/disk/by-id/* r,

Is that actually possible? I'm not sure. "lsscsi" is basically "ls" to list devices in the directory and here is the log.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: this change is not yet merged. Why are we merging this before the change is fixed in Ceph ? Am I missing something ?

with cephadm we're assimilating the config keys generated at this level: if the Ceph PR is not merged and that config doesn't exists, it's just ignored [2]. This means we can merge this patch before and having the feature enabled "for free" when the patch [1] lands.

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/45469
[2] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v16.2.9/src/mon/ConfigMonitor.cc#L659-L662

My concern is that the interface might be changed unless the patch has been merged. If any change is made in the parmaeter interface then that would cause a problem or requires additional update, which I believe we should avoid.

I'd not block this in case you need this now "for some reason" but please consider keeping the TODO to check the PR later to confirm the actual commit is consistent with current expectation.

Originally, this doc included an introduction section that had the answer for most questions asked here. This section was dropped as the doc focused in presenting this feature as a Kubernetes feature instead of a StarlingX feature, which is a valid approach. This section is shown below for reference.


"About the feature

  As stated in the reference documentation of the feature at https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/audit/ ,
"Kubernetes auditing provides a security-relevant, chronological set of records documenting the sequence of actions in a cluster. The cluster audits the activities generated by users, by applications that use the Kubernetes API, and by the control plane itself."
  The user configures which events should be logged through a set of rules written in a YAML file. The reference for this file is present at https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug/debug-cluster/audit/#audit-policy . A default policy file is provided in StarlingX at "/etc/kubernetes/default-audit-policy.yaml". This default policy file is a version of the audit profile for Google Container-Optimized OS.
  This Kubernetes feature is configured through kube-apiserver parameters. They are discussed in the following section. After, it is pointed out how to configure these parameters in StarlingX."

The section that describes the current limitations is missing:

"
Limitations

  A custom policy file can only be created at bootstrap time in "apiserver_extra_volumes" section. If a custom policy file was configured at bootstrap, then after bootstrap the user has the option to configure the parameter "audit-policy-file" to either this custom policy file ("/etc/kubernetes/my-audit-policy-file.yml" in the example above) or the default policy file "/etc/kubernetes/default-audit-policy.yaml". If no custom policy file was configured at bootstrap, then the user can only configure the parameter "audit-policy-file" to the default policy file. A way to use a custom policy when no custom policy file was configured at bootstrap is to edit the contents of default policy file before enabling the feature, but the user needs root access to edit this file.
  Only the parameter "audit-policy-file" is configurable after bootstrap, so the others ("audit-log-path", "audit-log-maxsize", "audit-log-maxage" and "audit-log-maxbackup") cannot be changed at runtime.
"

@jakub confirmed both the points with ramishra:-
<ykarel> ramishra, releases where ephemeral heat is not used, if during initial deployment if we pass a parameter_defaults: x=y(which mainly used to set hieradata on nodes)
<ykarel> what happens if we miss the passing that parameter in next overcloud deploy/update?

<ykarel> ramishra, Thanks, and now in recent release where swift is not there, how it happens now?
<ramishra> ykarel: parameters are in heat stack environments, PATCH update merges them, with ephemeral heat it won't be the case, the default for the parameter would be used
Thanks Yatin. Does it mean we're good here?

Maybe it's just lack of my knowledge of TripleO. The purpose of this patch is to avoid exactly that. That means, if we run 'overcloud deploy' with customized OVNIntegrationBridge and then in the next update we don't define OVNIntegrationBridge and leave it unset, where it will take the br-migration from? When I asked around, I understood it will use whatever is currently set in the hieradata, therefore this patch.

@jakub It doesn't matter if ovn-extras is used during upgrade/update, as overcloud plan already contains OVNIntegrationBridge from ovn-extras during the migration, it will get used for further update/upgrades unless it get's reset, before this patch it used to be reset by second tripleo-update call. This only applies to releases before wallaby, with wallaby+ there is no plan, so whatever explicitly pass will be used
Forgot to mention you don't need any plan, stack, heiradata update. That environment is always used and it would override what's there in plan/stack in next update (unless user environment has it).

I'm not sure I understand. Just note that ovn-extras is only used for the migration. The deploy command during upgrade/update must not use the ovn-extras, therefore OVNIntegrationBridge won't be set anywhere explicitly.
Thanks Rabi, I think that's the best and fastest solution. I'll send patches and request backporst.

If you want br-int (or whatever the user provides) and not br-migration to be used in the next update (after migration), we can set the default 'br-int' in https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/train/overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml#L377. That would be used in every deploy unless overridden with -e ovn-extras.yaml and we don't need any hack here.

This will work for OSP17 too.

OVNIntegrationBridge: br-int

@jakub you are right wrt hieradata is used, but hieradata get's generated during deploy/update and for this case it will be based on value of parameter "OVNIntegrationBridge". Since it was set to br-migration in previous step, the plan have that value so even if you drop "-e ovn-extras.yaml" from overcloud-deploy command the values are used from what's in the plan, and to fix it either update the plan with the expected value or pass -e ovn-extras.yaml with correct params(br-int) in overcloud deploy command.

This is my understanding but i will confirm with guys have more understanding, also now i have doubt on how it will work where swift/heat are removed from undercloud i.e with ephemeral heat based deployments(may be it will just work as it relies on whatever passed to deploy command, as no plan now), so will check that too with TripleO guys.

cinderclient/v3/shell.py.message:
I think we should handle 'server_id' like the way 'size' (nargs='?') is handled here.  If you do 

  cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.latest help create

you get something like this:

  usage: cinder create [--consisgroup-id <consistencygroup-id>]
                       ... etc ...
                       [<size>]

  Creates a volume.

  Positional Arguments:
    <size>                Size of volume, in GiBs. (Required unless snapshot-
                          id/source-volid/backup-id is specified).

  Optional Arguments:
    --consisgroup-id <consistencygroup-id>
                          ID of a consistency group where the new volume belongs
                          to. Default=None.

You can tell that 'size' is optional because of the '[<size>]' in the usage statement.  This way, we won't break shell scripts that are using attachment-create in the current way, i.e., as a positional arg.  Otherwise, people will have to update scripts to add the '--server-id' option.
See my comment above at line 586 for a different way to handle this.

Is there a usability issue here if the VLANs don't have names in the switch config? Does it make them harder to differentiate? I suppose it depends how often we see the name without the description.

An alternative solution would be to allow setting a maximum name length, then truncating the name.

Good question, thanks. Usability is fine: even "show vlan" displays the VLAN description instead of the VLAN name. To be honest, I haven't found a single place in the CLI where VLAN names are used or displayed. And having empty VLAN names seems to work just fine.

Allowing names to be truncated could indeed be a more general solution. But for this specific case, it would require the administrator to first be aware of the issue, and then configure "ngs_network_name_format" as well as this hypothetical new "max length" setting.
